pros: Everyone is friendly on campus.
cons: Low pay for the work involved.

job_title: Student Writing Tutor in Conway, SC
pros: The staff at the Writing Center is friendly and cultivates a team environment. Furthermore, the school is more than willing to work around your class schedule, so there's a lot of flexibility in being a working student.
cons: Sometimes the students are less than respectful, but if any of them cause true problems, management is always right on top of things and willing to step in.

pros: Structured processes make it somewhat easy and consistent to do your job
cons: TOXIC TOXIC TOXIC Leadership in the Department of University Housing and Division of Auxillary Enterprises. Just don't work in University Housing, but the entire university is a mess too. The location is TRASH. There is nothing to do. The leadership in University Housing does not care of the employees or the residents. They only care about their facilities, not the students who occupy them.

review_title: Teal Nation is a great place to work
pros: Coastal is a community willing to work to better employee's work life balance.
cons: It's in Conway and not in a very diverse area.

job_title: Resident Athletic Trainer in Conway, SC
pros: Autonomy out of grad school
cons: No structure, horrible organization of department

pros: People are nice to work with. They really care about the students
cons: Area is becoming more expensive and salaries need to keep up. Housing is unaffordable

job_title: Social Media Coordinator in Conway, SC
pros: Great for students when they're attending college.
cons: It can only be temp as many years you are with them

review_title: There are better places to work.
pros: Coworkers made the job bearable.
cons: Too many to list, wouldn't know where to begin.

pros: You get to know your professors better and help them with research projects. Lots of time to do schoolwork
cons: Often strange hours Lots of random tasks like filling printers and emptying shredders.

pros: Nice place to work, beautiful campus, respectful and pleasant colleagues, requirements for research are achievable, shared governance is taken seriously.
cons: Myrtle Beach and Conway are beautiful but are generally old, conservative, and lacking in vibrancy or diversity. Great university in a location that doesn’t “feel” like a college town, or a location of a university. Pay can be very low for staff persons. The handling of Pandemic issues were slow and overall reflective of conservative state government interference and not the science available in real time.

pros: Friendly Faculty, very supportive and knowledgable
cons: Some minor managerial issues but not bothered me

review_title: Great people (for the most part) but low pay and non-existent salary increases
pros: By the beach, great co-workers, and high campus spirit
cons: Salaries never get increased despite constant promises to do so. Employee morale struggles to be high due to the lack of understanding and support from university administration.

pros: I like the students a lot
cons: The accounting chair is the most negative person to both faculty and staff of any person I’ve ever met. The Dean did not have the spine or the brains to see through the chair. The accounting numbers are dropping consistently and turnover in the department is atrocious. The issues stem from nepotism, poor leadership and putting the bottom line over students. When you have a chair that laughs at students failing, you have a failing system.

pros: Location is the only pro about this place.
cons: The corruption that goes on at this college is beyond belief. They fill provost positions with people not having the qualification to do the job. There are unrealistic demands on the department. The pay is low. The technology, policies, and processes are 2 decades behind all other universities. People make up policies and practices as they go or as they feel fit at the time. This school is all about athletics and not academics. Coastal recently got a 10 mil gift to start a health school and has decided to use the majority of funds (8Mil) will go to build an indoor football practice facility. STAY AWAY

job_title: Assistant Director of Financial Aid in Conway, SC
pros: It's near the beach. Nothing else is a pro about working here
cons: The management is terrible. They're set in their ways and think that just because they were a student there, and that's how it was done 10+ years ago, that things aren't broken and don't need to be fixed. Only one person in the office was ever welcoming to me otherwise I was seen as an outsider and only tolerated.

pros: State agency benefits and job security.
cons: The cost of living is high.

pros:
Students are wonderful!
Clear communication
cons: They consider adjunct faculty to be the same as T.A.s and rarely offer a contract from HR before the first week of classes (this has happened to me 3 times, the last time I was not formally hired until the second week of classes).

pros: Annual and sick leave is great
cons: Pay at CCU is not good.

pros: I enjoyed the job itself. Loved my co workers.
cons: Not a lot of transparency. There is a lot of red tape

pros: Beautiful campus and great location just 12 miles from the beach. Advisement just implemented a centralized, decentralized model, which is great. There are plans to hire many additional advisors over the next few years as we transition to four year advising.
cons: The technology used for academic advising is archaic. WebAdvisor, Beacon, and home grown systems that are incredibly inefficient. Advisors are expected to “build” schedules for students that do not register themselves. We’re definitely not following NACADA best practices. Additionally, I often feel that I’m performing basic data entry instead of meaningful academic advising with students.

job_title: Assistant Director, Residence Life in Conway, SC
pros: Caring environment, friendly people, and fair pay
cons: Health care plan is not the best I’ve had

pros: Great workspace and employees to build connections
cons: Human Resources needs some work

pros: Working as a student assistant allows a flexible schedule to give you time to focus on your schoolwork.
cons: Pay is mostly minimum wage

cons: Some students may want to work more hours than allowed.

pros: Good benefits and nice people.
cons: Low pay/management could make better effort to play to employees strengths

pros: Easy job to have while completing a degree
cons: Management is not the most organized

pros: Beach is nearby and community is growing

review_title: Pretty fair for a low stress job

cons: low pay and you could get more doordashing in your spare time

pros: Not much physical labor, calm and relaxed enviornment.
cons: Not good pay or good hours for student worker.

pros: So much potential!  Solid programs, right-sized with great stud.- professor ratios..  A great fine arts/music program, strong business and education schools, excellent library, wonderful professors!  An ever-growing FTE and growth run rampant, but so much emphasis put on silly presidential vanity initiatives.
cons: Old boys club, so many blatant mid-mgmt. problems but those who should handle these things would rather not.  Rapidly growing FTE, move to Div. IA Sports, but admin behaves as if the school is almost broke.  Rampant micro-management, treat education as a commodity or as if we are in a service industry.  Would rather "feel the teal" than create and foster excellent educational programs and initiatives.

pros: Great Professors that are willing to work with students
cons: Could use more student engagement

pros: amazing work environment and people
cons: nothing is bad about this position

review_title: Rewarding work but difficult to advance
pros: The campus is beautiful and there are many options for lunch
cons: It is difficult to move up even though CCU prefers to hire from within

pros: Coastal Carolina has great school spirit and a beautiful campus.
cons: The organization could use to be improved.

pros: it is very family oriented
cons: hard to advance in career

review_title: Directional State U with Average Leadership
job_title: Instructional Designer in Myrtle Beach, SC
pros: Flexibility, close-knit faculty and staff feel
cons: No clear direction, strategy, not enough resources (people or money) to be great

pros: Nice environment and people to work with.
cons: It could use a little more excitement in the area.

job_title: Athletics Media Graduate Assistant in Conway, SC
pros: Growing school, exciting to be a part of
cons: Conway location, short staffed due to Covid

pros: The community here is great
cons: I have no cons. This is a great place.

pros: Great company to work for.
cons: The pay isn’t all that well

pros: Extremely supportive administration, faculty, and staff across campus. Students, on average, are engaged. Facilities are excellent.
cons: Pay is not good. This, it seems, is because it is a state university in South Carolina. Downtown Conway is quaint, though much of the Myrtle Beach area (which is contiguous with Conway and has most places of interest) is unattractive. The population is, by and large, conservative and uneducated, largely because it is in the state of South Carolina. State health insurance provider's costs, for what you receive, are horrifically outlandish, though this should be expected since CCU is located in SC.

pros: It is a plus to be able to take a classes for free and have access to the gym and recreational facilities, good benefit package and my fellow staff are wonderful. There is daily flexibility, you can come in a little late and stay late to make up the time, it's not a strict punch in/punch out environment.
cons: There is limited opportunity for growth, networking and professional development beyond the hallowed walls- depending on the department you are in. Being in the sciences, these opportunities are important but not readily available to staff. There are specific funding pools for faculty and administrative staff to pursue opportunities, but nothing for research staff. I don't feel as though the University is invested in my future success, though I've brought in money in my short tenure. Very simple employee issues are overlooked, the staff in my area don't get business cards making networking a little more difficult when the opportunities arise.

pros: It is not bad to live near the beach, especially after the tourists leave.
cons: There are so many downsides to Coastal that it is hard to know where to begin. The Dean was quite dishonest to me on several occasions. The students are not too bright on the whole, and many are recruited from out-of-state to pay tuition. These students tend to have a consumerist mentality: I am paying for this so you have to give me high marks. In particular, the Dean of LIberal Arts is a shaky (at best) scholar with a reputation for throwing faculty under the bus if it makes him look good to the higher ups.Overall, CCU is a joke, only for unambitious profs and those who just want to slide by. I would NEVER send a child of mine to such a school.

pros: I got to do my homework and get paid while waiting for students to come get help. Not only did I get my homework done, but as I tutored the lower level Econ classes, it refreshed my memory on the basics again so when it came time to take my exit exam with all the core classes, I did well on my Economics portion because the tutoring I did. Also there is the satisfaction of helping your peers pass their classes. When some thanked me and said they couldn't have done it without me, it was a very rewarding feeling.
cons: The teachers let kids retakes failed exams in hopes less people would drop the courses because ECON can be tough, so I had many people come in who didn't want to be there.

pros: Speaking for my own department, in the humanities, I am very satisfied.  I find my colleagues to be committed teachers and pretty smart scholars, especially the newer hires.  The administrative staff are top-notch.
cons:
Like many universities, Coastal is filled with anxiety about the future and lets itself be led around by the bean-counters.  There is a lack of vision at the top.  Some departments (for example, modern languages) have been gutted.  

The health benefits are the worst I've had.  I'm amazed at the deductible.

review_title: Standard academic beauracracy for a state university.
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Conway, SC
pros:
- Decent location, not too far from the beach, good for those who like the Myrtle Beach/Conway area. 
- Easy to have a personal relationship with others within each department.
cons:
- Too hot/humid in the summer, too cold in the winter, its only really nice for about a month in both the Spring and Fall.
- A lot of beauracracy.
- Limited weekly hours for student employees makes it difficult to work multiple student jobs.
- Students not able to work full-time over the summer (only allowed to work 37.5 hours) makes it difficult on students who are struggling to pay for college.

pros: Great environment,  beautiful campus, very nice people. community support,  fun events,  personable students.  Great weather and school spirit very encouraged!
cons: Good old boys system. Too much talk about politics and religion within professional settings. Men got promoted over females who were doing a much better job. Married females were promoted over unmarried females.  (Basically, it's 1952).

review_title: CCU is a great institution with some distinct strengths and weaknesses.
pros: Academic programs are basically, although some are more so than others.  The non-academic aspects are like a cruise ship - lots to do and great attention to detail in programming and success.  The university is growing when most are struggling. University administration pays close attention to making sure everything looks good.
cons: Academic leadership seems generally more concerned with appearance than quality.  Support by administration of faculty is very uneven and appears to reflect both favoritism and cronyism.

pros: Working at a state institution in South Carolina, at this time, you only have to work 37.5 hours per week. My department has an excellent administrator who is flexible when warranted. I also have a great deal of autonomy to do my job well.
cons: State benefits in South Carolina are not very good and there is very little room to rise in these types of positions. Also, the state is not known to give raises often for staff positions.

pros: Competitive salaries, flexible scheduling of classes, new facilities
cons: The bar is held very low for students by many professors. The professors are rewarded for increasing retention rates by passing students who have not learned the material.

pros: I gained a ton of experience with printing and juggling multiple projects at one time. Was extremely helpful for real life experiences and client expectations. My boss was and is still a great mentor. I appreciated all the experience this position provided me and had a lot of good feedback during the interviewing process post college graduation. Plus, portfolio pieces!
cons: Lots of work with high expectations - but will make you a better designer!!

review_title: As a student and worker of Coastal Carolina University, I was able to sustain my college career.
pros: My professors and employer was caring and offered a huge support.
cons: Benefits at work could have been more consistent.

review_title: They are a great place to work!
pros: They have their ups and downs! I enjoy the state benefits and the access to free classes a semester!
cons: They have their issues as far as management, people get in a position and it takes an act of god to get them out because of all the politics.

review_title: Great Job for a Graduate Student
pros: Great pay for the work, total comp. is greater than hourly pay if you consider tuition stipend for out of state students, enjoyable staff and you get some opportunities to choose the type of work you can do.
cons: Not really any advancement opportunities, but that is not really what you expect from this position. Other than that, not really any cons at all.

pros:
-Team Building
-Friendly Staff
-Great on a Resume
-Paid Housing & Meals
-Nice Living Facilities
cons:
-Long Training
-May have to share a suite
-Can be Clickish depending on staff given
-Work/ Life Balance around beginning and end of the semester is hard because of all the check ins/outs

pros: I was able to work around my schedule and work in the department I loved. I was able to teach to those that needed help.
cons: Sometimes I would have to tutor in classes I haven't taken, but It wasn't too challenging to look at the material and help.

job_title: Teaching Associate in San Diego, CA
pros: As a part time employee, there were not a lot of pros. I was lucky for my class to make each semester because if it did, it was often taken by a full timer whose class did not make.
cons: Pay was a little on the low side for adjunct pay

pros: If you are determined and apply to many positions as a student, you are bound to get a job.
cons: The pay cap is at minimum wage, so unless you have extensive certification or training you won't be getting a raise.

pros: Good location and low cost of living
cons: Lack of a sense of community and belonging at the University

review_title: The Wall College of Business is great place to work and study!
pros: The people are very friendly and will try to help you in anyway they can.
cons: The communication on the campus is nonexistent. Everyone likes to assume things are getting done instead checking or rechecking to make sure.

pros: Beautiful campus, nice living near the beach
cons: Negative culture in the college, decisions made by very few even though the current Dean makes you think it's a college wide decision. I say current dean because In the last ten years, there have been four deans, and I don't expect this dean will last either.

pros: Community, family-friendly, great place to work as an introductory career or if you're a professor in Business

pros: Relaxed, short shifts, friendly managers

pros: Great Pay, Flexible hours, helps pay for Grad School!

pros: Flexible, dependable, incredible adaptability, and friendly faces!
